titleStmt.title: A new method for probabilistic linguistic multi-attribute group decision making: application to the selection of financial technologies

affiliation.orgName: Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics
Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics
Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics

Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics

analytic.title: A new method for probabilistic linguistic multi-attribute group decision making: application to the selection of financial technologies

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: No technology, no financial" has been the consensus in banking industry. Under the background of financial technology (Fintech), how to select an appropriate technology company to cooperate for the banks has become a key. The technology company selection can be regarded as a kind of multi-attribute group decision making (MAGDM) problems. The probabilistic linguistic term set (PLTS) is a useful tool to express decision makers' (DMs') evaluations in the technology company selection. This paper develops a new method for MAGDM with PLTSs. Firstly, the possibility degree and range value of PLTSs are defined. Then a possibility degree algorithm is designed for ranking

PLTSs. An Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs is presented and extended to probabilistic linguistic matrices. Based on Archimedean t-norm and s-norm, some new operational laws for PLTSs are defined and some desirable properties are discussed. Then, a generalized probabilistic linguistic Hamacher weighted averaging (GPLHWA) operator and a generalized probabilistic linguistic Hamacher ordered weighted averaging (GPLHOWA) operator are developed. Some useful properties for these operators are investigated in detail. Combined with the subjective weights of DMs, the DMs' weights are determined by the adjusted coefficients. Using the GPLHWA operator, the collective decision matrix is obtained by aggregating all the individual decision matrices. By maximizing the total weighted square possibility degree, a multi-objective program is constructed to derive the attribute weights. The ranking order of alternatives is generated by integrating ELECTRE and TOPSIS. Thereby, a new method is put forward for MAGDM with PLTSs. A Fintech example is analyzed to show the effectiveness of the proposed method. The sensitivity analysis and comparative analyses are conducted

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In 2016, the State Council issued the "Thirteen Five" National Science and Technology Innovation Plan. The plan focuses on the integration of science, technology and finance deeply.

Science and technology gradually changed the development mode of financial industry. The financial technology (abbreviated as Fintech hereinafter) has become a hot topic. To cope with increasingly fierce competition, it is necessary for banks to transform by cooperating with technology companies.

How to select the proper technology company is the most crucial question for a bank. Since the technology companies can be evaluated from different aspects, the selection of technology company can be as ascribed to a kind of multi-attribute decision making (MADM) problems [1][2][3][4]. To increase the efficiency of Fintech in complex financial environment, banks often invite multiple decision makers (DMs) to participate together in making decision for technology company selection. Therefore, technology company selection may be formulated as a type of multi-attribute group decision making (MAGDM) problems [5][6][7][8][9], which can make decision making more reasonable and reliable.

Due to complexity and uncertainty of the practical problems, DMs inevitably encounter the dilemma of hesitation and fuzziness. Under such situation, DMs tend to express their preferences by qualitative linguistic terms instead of precise quantitative numbers. Consequently, a number of linguistic models emerged continuously, such as semantic model [10], symbolic model [11] and linguistic 2-tuple model [12,13], interval 2-tuple linguistic model [14], linguistic hesitant fuzzy model [15], etc. These models have received extensive attention and applied widely to various fields [16,17].
Xu [18] proposed a subscript-symmetric additive linguistic term set (LTS). Then Xu [19] further extended the discrete LTS to the continuous LTS and introduce the virtual linguistic term (VLT).

Besides, Xu and Wang [20] specified the syntax and semantics of VLTs so as to serve as the theoretical foundation of computational models. However, the linguistic 2-tuple proposed by Herrera and Martínez [12] is only suitable for LTSs that are uniformly and symmetrically distributed. In fact, LTSs are not always uniformly and symmetrically distributed under real-life decision making situations. To manage such situations, Wang and Hao [21] provided the proportional two-tuple linguistic representation model assigning symbolic proportions to two successive linguistic terms in a linguistic term set. Inspired by the model of Wang and Hao [21], Zhang et al. [22] proposed the concept of linguistic distribution assessment, in which symbolic proportions can be assigned to all of the linguistic terms in a linguistic term sets. Moreover, Zhang et al. [22] and Zhang et al. [23] investigated the expectation, inaccuracy function, comparison rules and some aggregation operators of the linguistic distribution assessment.

Based on the linguistic distribution, Dong et al. [24] further introduced the linguistic distribution with interval symbolic proportions in multi-granular unbalanced linguistic context. Sometimes, the traditional approach characterized by single linguistic term does not meet DMs' demand for expressing preference information. For example, when evaluating the sharpness of one camera, DMs hesitate to choose one of "good", "a little good" or "pretty good". To address this issue, Rodríguez et al. [25] proposed hesitant fuzzy linguistic term sets (HFLTSs) that assess a concept using several linguistic terms with equal weight provided by DMs. That is to say, HFLTSs take DMs' hesitation into consideration. Xu et al. [26] developed hesitant fuzzy linguistic LINMAP (Linear Programming Technique for Multidimensional Analysis of Preference) method to solve MADM problems with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information. Furthermore, Xu et al. [27] studied the consistency and consensus models with local adjustment strategy for hesitant fuzzy linguistic preference relations (HFLPRs). To describe hesitant and incomplete evaluation information in the group decision making (GDM) process，the incomplete fuzzy preference relations have received great attention [28][29][30][31].

Motivated by the linguistic distribution and HFLTSs, Wu and Xu [32] proposed possibility distribution-based approach for MAGDM with HFLTSs. Chen et al. [33] introduced proportional HFLTSs considering hesitant fuzzy assessments of DMs and proportional information of each linguistic term in MAGDM. However, the HFLTSs may not be appropriate for linguistic term with different weights. For example, a DM is 60% sure that the sharpness of one camera is "good", 30% thinks that it is "a little good", and only 10% believes that it is "pretty good". To better overcome the limitation, Pang et al. [5] proposed probabilistic linguistic term sets (PLTSs), which not only capture the linguistic evaluation information on an object, but also reflect the corresponding probability information. In some cases, DMs cannot provide symbolic proportion information for simple linguistic term. Instead, they may hesitate among several consecutive terms and provide a sum of proportions for an HFLTS. To address such a case, Zhang et al. [34] introduced the hesitant fuzzy distribution and its aggregation operators. In addition, a comparison made by Zhang et al. [34] showed that the hesitant fuzzy distribution is a general linguistic expression, generalizing different variants of linguistic distribution.

The difference between PLTS and the linguistic distribution is that the sum of the symbolic proportions of all linguistic terms can be less than 1 in a PLTS. But, PLTSs are transformed into linguistic distributions for computing. Thereby, PLTS is a powerful technique to deal with more complex uncertainties [35]. Many progresses have been made on PLTSs. These achievements can be divided into five categories: methods of ranking PLTSs, distance measure of PLTSs, operational laws for PLTSs, methods for solving MADM or MAGDM with PLTSs and probabilistic linguistic preference relation (PLPR). For instance, the score function and deviation degree of PLTSs were defined to compare PLTSs [5]. But the comparison result derived by method [5] does not meet common sense sometimes, because it may be unreasonable to say one PLTS is absolutely superior to the other if two PLTSs have some common linguistic terms [36].To overcome this weakness, Bai et al. [36] developed a possibility degree formula to rank PLTSs. Then Pang et al. [5] and Zhang et al. [37] both defined the distance measure between PLTSs. Besides, Pang et al. [5] put forward some basic operational laws for PLTSs, Zhang et al. [37] defined some operations for PLTSs as well. Based on transformation function, Gou and Xu [38] redefined the operational laws for PLTSs and discussed their properties. Additionally, the extended TOPSIS and aggregation-based methods were developed for MAGDM with probabilistic linguistic information in [5]. Subsequently, Bai et al. [36] proposed a decision making framework to solve real-life problems and Liao et al. [2] proposed a linear programming method to solve the MADM problem under probabilistic linguistic environment. Finally, Zhang et al. [37] introduced the PLPR. Then a method is presented to solve consistency-based risk assessment with PLPR. Zhang et al. [39] focused on the consensus reaching process for GDM with PLPRs and developed a GDM method based on the aggregation operators of PLTSs. Although there are many research findings on PLTSs, they still suffer from some limitations. These limitations are summarized from four aspects: methods of ranking PLTSs, distance measures of PLTSs, operational laws for PLTSs, methods for MADM or MAGDM with PLTSs.

(1) A preorder for two PLTSs defined by Pang et al. [5] does not provide the degree to which one PLTS is superior to another. The ranking method in [36] cannot distinguish some different PLTSs. In addition, it is complicated to compute the possibility degree formula of PLTSs (see Section 3.1.1 for more details).

(2) Using methods [5,37], the distances between two different PLTSs could be equal to zero in some cases, which may lead to some unreasonable or counterintuitive results under some circumstances (see Section 3.2.1 for more details).

(3) By the operational laws in [5,37], the operation results of some PLTSs may exceed the bounds of LTS. The operation results by [5] lose the corresponding probability information, which is unreasonable. The operational laws in [38] use the same way to deal with probability information on the addition and multiplication of PLTSs. In fact, any two PLTSs can be regarded as two independent random events. The probabilities of union and intersection of two independent random events should not be the same. For example, let a and b be two independent random events with the probabilities ( ) 0. , respectively. Thus, the probabilities of the addition and multiplication operations for PLTSs should be different.

(4) Methods [36,37,38] are only suitable for MADM with PLTSs. They cannot be used to solve MAGDM with PLTSs. Although methods [2,5,39] are provided for MAGDM with PLTSs, they ignored the importance of DMs. Therefore, the aforesaid methods are unable to solve some specific probabilistic linguistic MAGDM problems that can be solved by the proposed method of this paper.

To overcome the above defects, this paper proposes a new method to solve the probabilistic linguistic MAGDM problems. Firstly, a possibility degree algorithm is designed for ranking PLTSs. An Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs is defined and extended to probabilistic linguistic matrices.

Then some new operational laws for PLTSs are defined using Archimedean triangular norm (t-norm) and triangular conorm (t-conorm or s-norm) [40,41]. A generalized probabilistic linguistic Hamacher weighted averaging (GPLHWA) operator and a generalized probabilistic linguistic Hamacher ordered weighted averaging (GPLHOWA) operator are developed for PLTSs. Moreover, DMs' weights are determined by the consistent degree and adjusted coefficient of DMs. Using the GPLHWA operator, a collective matrix is obtained. Then a multi-objective program is constructed and transformed into a linear program to derive the attribute weights. The ranking order of alternatives is generated by integrating TOPSIS (Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution) [42] and ELECTRE (Elimination Et Choice Translation Reality) [43]. Thus, a new method is developed for MAGDM under probabilistic linguistic environment. The main contributions and features of this paper can be illuminated as follows:

(1) The possibility degree and the range value of PLTSs are defined. Then a possibility degree algorithm is designed to rank PLTSs, which can make full use of linguistic terms and probability information.
(2) Based on transformation function, an Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs is proposed and extended to probabilistic linguistic matrices. The new distance can distinguish two different PLTSs.
(3) Using Archimedean t-norm and s-norm, some new operational laws for PLTSs are provided and proven to be closed. Further, some new aggregating operators of PLTSs are proposed.

(4) Based on the subjective weights of DMs, the DMs' weights are determined by adjusted coefficients of DMs. Using the GPLHWA operator, the individual evaluations are aggregated into a collective matrix. The attribute weights are derived objectively by a multi-objective program. The ranking order of alternatives is generated by integrating ELECTRE and TOPSIS. Thus, a new method is proposed to solve MAGDM with PLTSs, which is more objective and reasonable.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: In section 2, some basic concepts are briefly reviewed. In section 3, a possibility degree algorithm is designed for ranking PLTSs and an Euclidean distance measure of PLTSs is proposed. In section 4, some new operational laws of PLTSs are defined based on Archimedean t-norm and s-norm. The GPLHWA and GPLHOWA operators are developed and some attractive properties are discussed. In section 5, the consistent degree and adjusted coefficient of DMs are defined to derive DMs' weights. A multi-objective program is constructed to derive the attribute weights. The ranking order of alternatives is obtained by integrating ELECTRE and TOPSIS.

Subsequently, a new method is proposed for MAGDM with PLTSs. In section 6, a case study on Fintech is provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed method. Some discussions are made in section 7. Finally, some conclusions are drawn in section 8.

div.head: Possibility degree algorithm for ranking PLTSs and Euclidean distance of PLTSs
div.p: A possibility degree algorithm is designed to rank PLTS. Then an Euclidean distance between PLTSs is defined and extended to probabilistic linguistic matrices.

div.head: A possibility degree algorithm for ranking PLTSs
div.p: Firstly, existing methods for ranking PLTSs are analyzed. Then, a possibility degree algorithm for ranking PLTSs is introduced.

Although the aforementioned two methods can be used to compare PLTSs, they more or less suffer from some shortcomings. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate a new algorithm for ranking PLTSs.

div.head: A possibility degree algorithm for ranking PLTSs

div.p: Remark 1. Any ranking method cannot be regarded as an absolutely reasonable one because of the presence of uncertainty. Different methods are proposed from diverse perspectives. This paper proposes the possibility degree algorithm for ranking PLTSs, which can not only rank PLTSs but also reflect the degree to which a PLTS is preferred to another. Although the possibility algorithm is not a total order for PLTSs, it can be applied for ranking most PLTSs except for PLTSs with equal superior index and range value. Thereby, the possibility algorithm for ranking PLTSs is of value to some extent.

div.head: An Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs
div.p: Firstly, existing distance measures between PLTSs are analyzed. Then an Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs is developed and extended to probabilistic linguistic matrices.

div.head: Existing distance measures between PLTSs

In view of the shortcomings of above definitions on distance between PLTSs, an Euclidean distance between PLTSs is defined on basis of the transformation function g (see Definition 2).

div.head: An Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs

(2) The proposed operational laws are closed, which is proved in Theorem 1. Therefore, the proposed operational laws overcome the defects in Refs [5,37,38]. Besides, four different types of operational laws for PLTSs are proposed based on different Archimedean t-norms and s-norms, DMs can chose various types of operational laws according to their preferences. Thus, the proposed operational laws enrich the ways of operating PLTSs from distinct angles.

div.head: New aggregation operators of PLTSs based on Hamacher t-norm and s-norm
div.p: Some probabilistic linguistic aggregation operators based on Hamacher operational laws are developed in this subsection. For convenience, let P be the set of all PLTSs.

div.head: A new method for MAGDM with probabilistic linguistic information
div.p: First of all, the MAGDM problems with probabilistic linguistic information are described. Then DMs' weights are determined by the adjusted coefficient and a multi-objective program is established to determine attribute weights. The ranking order of alternatives is generated. Finally, a new method for MAGDM with probabilistic linguistic information is developed. ( , , , )

div.head: Problem Description
div.p: is the weight vector of DMs, satisfying 0
All evaluations construct the decision matrices ( ( ))
div.formula: k k ij m n L p   U ( 1, 2, , ) k t   .

div.head: Determination of DMs' weights
div.p: Due to different fame, status, professional levels and other aspects of DMs, giving subjective weights of DMs in advance can be biased. For example, the largest subjective weight is given to DM k d with highest fame and status, but there are great divergences of judgment information between DM k d and the other DMs. To weaken the effect of DMs with higher fame and status, the subjective weights of DMs should be adjusted by an adjusted coefficient. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a scientific method to determine DMs' weights.

Based on the differences of the judgment information expressed by DMs, the adjusted coefficient is proposed to adjust the subjective weights of DMs. Higher adjusted coefficient is given to k d when judgment information of k d is more consistent with those provided by other DMs. On the contrary, lower adjusted coefficient is given to k d .
Based on the normalized decision matrices ( ( ))

div.head: Attribute weights derived by a multi-objective program
div.p: It is known to us that attribute weights play a critical role in decision making, the variation of attribute weights may have an effect on the final ranking of alternatives [50]. Owing to this fact, a novel method for determining attribute weights is developed based on possibility degree.
(1) Aggregating information Using DMs' weights vector  , aggregating all ( ( ))

div.formula: 2 1 1 1, ( ( ( ) ( ))) m m m i i l l i j ij j ij lj T T w P L p L p             ( 1, 2, , ) j n   . (44
div.p: According to Wang [51], an attribute with little difference on evaluation values among alternatives should be assigned a smaller weight, while an attribute with big difference on evaluation values among alternatives should be assigned a larger weight. Based on these analyses, it is reasonable to determine the attribute weight vector w such that the total weighted square possibility degree j T on an attribute j a is maximized. Hence, a multi-objective programming model is established: 45) is transformed into a single objective program as:

div.head: A new method for MAGDM with probabilistic linguistic information
div.p: A new method is developed for MAGDM with probabilistic linguistic information. The main procedure of this method is summarized as follows:
Step 1: Form probabilistic linguistic matrices ( ( ))
div.formula: k k ij m n L p   U ( 1, 2, , ) k t 

div.head: Case study
div.p: In this section, an example on Fintech is illustrated to validate the application of the proposed Meanwhile, the sensitivity analysis and comparative analyses are also conducted to show the superiority of the proposed method.

div.head: Application to the Fintech
div.p: The Fintech is a technology-driven financial innovation that injects new vitality into financial institutions such as banks. Fintech is a new gene for banks. Up to now, five banks have reached a strategic cooperation with Baidu, Alibaba and ants gold clothes, Tencent, Jingdong, Suning companies.
Thereby, it is significant for other banks to choose an appropriate technology company to establish a cooperative relationship.
Suppose that one bank chooses a befitting company from four companies (i.e., alternatives) i x

( 1, 2,3, 4) i  to establish cooperative relationship. Generally, the following four abilities (i.e., attributes) are given, such as cloud computing 1 a , big data 2 a , artificial intelligence 3 a and block chain 4 a . Three DMs 1 d , 2 d and 3 d are invited to assess these four alternatives on four attributes.

Meanwhile, the given subjective weight vector of DMs is T (0. . The ratings of alternatives on attributes provided by DMs are represented by PLTSs. Thus, the probabilistic linguistic matrices 1 U , 2 U and 3 U are formed.
Step 1: The decision matrices 1 U , 2 U and 3 U are elicited in Table 3, and the corresponding ascending-ordered normalized matrices 1 U , 2 U and 3 U are showed in Table 4. .
Step 3: Set 1   , 1   , a collective normalized decision matrice  U is generated as:
Solving Eq. (66), the optimal solution is obtained as T (0.2335,0.2781, 0.2489, 0.2394)  
. By Eq. ( 54), the attribute weights are obtained as T (0.2418,0.2638,0.2496,0.2448)  w .

div.head: Sensitivity analysis
div.p: In Step 3, GPLHWA operator is used to aggregate DMs' decision matrices into a collective one.

However, the ranking order of alternatives may vary with the values of parameters  and  . To help users (or readers, practitioners) set appropriate parameters, it necessary to do the sensitivity analyses of the parameters  and  . With different  and  , the corresponding ranking orders of alternatives are obtained and presented in Table 8.

As can be seen form Table 8, it is concluded that the ranking order of alternatives is not sensitive to the values of  and  . Although GPLHWA operator is only applied to aggregate DMs' decision matrices, it should be noticed that any tiny alteration on evaluations would not affect outranking relations. As a result, the ranking of alternatives keeps unchanged. Due to arbitrariness of DMs and random error, there are some differences between given evaluations and actual evaluations of DMs.
Thus, compared with previous decision making methods [38,54,55], the proposed method of this paper is more robust and cannot be influenced by arbitrariness.

div.head: Comparative analyses
div.p: To show the advantages of the proposed method, comparative analyses with the PL-LINMAP method [2] and the PLWA aggregation operator-based method [5] are performed in the sequel.

div.head: Comparison with the PL-LINMAP method
div.p: Liao et al. [2] proposed the PL-LINMAP method to solve MAGDM. Suppose that the preference information of incomplete paired alternatives is provided as

[2] to solve the above example, the weighted deviation squares and the Borda's scores of all alternatives are shown in Table 9 and Table 10, respectively. According to Table 10, the ranking order of alternatives is 2 1 3 4
x x x x    . Obviously, the best alternative is 2

x , which is the same as that obtained by the method proposed in this paper. However, the ranking of alternatives is different from that obtained by the proposed method, which can be explained by the following reasons:

(1) The PL-LINMAP method in [2] does not take DMs' weights into consideration. Conversely, this paper not only considers DMs' weights but also makes an adjustment on subjective weights of DMs. Hence, the result generated by the proposed method is more reasonable and convincible.

(2) The preference information  is provided by DMs in PL-LINMAP method [2], which is of subjectivity and arbitrariness to some extent. The ranking order of the alternatives may be changed as the various preference information provided by the different DMs or the same DMs in different periods.
However, the proposed method can avoid such limitation by constructing outranking relations.

div.head: Comparison with the PLWA aggregation operator-based method
div.p: The PLWA aggregation operator-based method [5] is used to solve the example in section 6.1. The ranking order of the alternatives is obtained as 2 3 4 1
x x x x    , the best alternative is 2

x . Although the best alternative obtained by method [5] is the same as that obtained by the proposed method of this paper, the ranking orders of the alternatives are different. The primary reasons may come from two aspects below:

(1) Pang et al. [5] uses PLWA operator (Eq. ( 15) in [5]) to aggregate DMs' decision matrices into a collective matrix and obtain overall values of alternatives. The aggregating results are HFLTSs instead of PLTSs, which means that PLWA operator leads to loss of probability information. By contrast, the collective matrix is obtained by GPLHWA operator (Eq. ( 20)) in this paper. Apparently the aggregating results are still PLTSs. The proposed method avoids loss of information and makes full use of evaluations as much as possible. Therefore, the result obtained by the proposed method is more actual and credible.

(2) Pang et al. [5] ranks the alternatives based on the score and deviation degree. It can be found from section 3.1.1 that Pang et al.'s preorder is not robust. Conversely, the proposed method ranks the alternatives integrating TOPSIS and ELECTRE. Tiny perturbation may not change the outranking relations so that the final ranking order keeps stable.

div.head: Discussions
div.p: In this section, some advantages and limitations of the proposed method are presented.
(1) The advantages of the proposed method are summarized from linguistic decision making and MADM.

(i) Linguistic decision making: It is vital to how to compute with words in linguistic decision making problems. Various numerical scale models [56][57][58][59] (ii) MADM: Although Dong et al. [62] provided a feasible model to solve the complex and dynamic MAGDM problem, they gave the DMs' weights a priori, whereas this paper determines objectively the DMs' weights based on evaluation information. In Dong et al. [63], the strategic manipulation of the MADM are introduced and a series of 0-1 mixed linear programming models to show the process of designing a strategic attribute weight vector. The method [63] does not take the multiple DMs and fuzziness of evaluation information into consideration. However, the proposed method can effectively solve the MAGDM problems in probabilistic linguistic environment.
(2) The limitations of the proposed method are also summarized from linguistic decision making and MADM.

(i) Linguistic decision making: Most of existing studies focued on linguistic computational models [56][57][58][59] and interpreting semantics [60,61]. On the contrary, the proposed method of this paper ignores that the semantics should play a critical role in probabilistic linguistic MAGDM. Furthermore, it is necessary to consider probabilistic linguistic computational model with LTSs that are uniformly and symmetrically distributed.

(ii) MADM: Compared with the methods [62,63], the proposed method is based on premises that the sets of attributes for all DMs are exactly the same and the DMs are the honest. The personalization and psychological behavior of DMs are not considered in this paper.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Fintech is more and more prevalent in banking industry. The technology company selection is a crucial strategy for banks, which can be regarded as a MAGDM problem. The PLTS is a power tool to capture the various opinions of DMs in complicated MAGDM. In this paper, the possibility algorithm is devised to rank PLTSs and the Euclidean distance measure between PLTSs is proposed firstly. Some new operational laws for PLTSs and aggregation operators of PLTSs are developed, such as PLHWA, GPLHWA, PLHOWA and GPLHOWA operators. Besides, the properties of these operators are studied, including boundedness, monotonicity and commutativity. Then DMs' weights are determined by the adjusted coefficients and subjective weights of DMs. The collective decision matrix is obtained by the GPLHWA operator. By maximizing the total weighted square possibility degree, a multi-objective program is constructed to derive the attribute weights. The ranking order of alternatives is generated integrating ELECTRE and TOPSIS. Therefore, a new method is developed for solving MAGDM under probabilistic linguistic environment. At length, a Fintech example is provided to show the effectiveness and priorities of the method proposed in this paper.

Although the financial technologies selection example is given to validate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method, it can be employed to solve many practical decision making problems, such as supply chain management, investment selection, police effect evaluation, etc. In the future, the family of probabilistic linguistic Hamacher weighted geometric operators will be studied in depth. In addition, some probabilistic linguistic Frank operators deserve to be investigated extensively based on the Frank t-norm and s-norm.

have been investigated together with 2-tuple linguistic representation model. In addition, Li et al.[60] and Li et al.[61] both proposed personalized individual semantics models to capture different meanings for different DMs. Models[56][57][58][59][60][61] are only suitable for linguistic decision problems where DMs provide preference by linguistic preference relations. In contrast, the proposed possibility degree algorithm, operational laws and aggregating operators of PLTSs of this paper can not only serve for PLPRs but also deal with probabilistic linguistic MADM or MAGDM.
